awd_abstract_narration:
Symplectic geometry is an area of mathematics that dates back to the 19th century and the modern formulation in physics of Newtonian mechanics. In the past few decades, it has become an exciting and fundamental area of mathematical research, due in part to close connections with many other parts of mathematics as well as physics. Symplectic geometry has had especially striking recent applications to low-dimensional topology, the mathematical study of three- and four-dimensional spaces. The Principal Investigator will pursue one particularly promising technique along these lines, in the setting of the theory of knots, or loops of string that are tied together at their ends. This technique has proven to be of interest to the physics community, providing tantalizing clues of an as-yet-undiscovered framework that combines portions of mathematics (in particular, symplectic geometry) and theoretical physics (in particular, string theory, which provides a model for the fundamental forces that shape the universe). The present project will work to uncover this framework, facilitating the exchange of ideas between mathematics and physics. As part of this project, the Principal Investigator will also promote the training of future mathematicians, running research programs and mathematical competitions for both undergraduate students and local high school students.

The unifying approach to symplectic geometry in this project is provided by holomorphic curves. Since pioneering work by Gromov in the 1980s, holomorphic curves have become a central tool in symplectic geometry, combining powerful analytical and geometric techniques with a computable combinatorial flavor. The research supported by this award applies holomorphic curves to the setting of knots. Previous work by the Principal Investigator and collaborators led to the development of knot contact homology, a powerful knot invariant in the spirit of Symplectic Field Theory, which has evolved into a subject that has many unexpected and intriguing connections to various areas of mathematics and physics. Recent results have opened the door to a detailed exploration of these connections, which will be carried out in this project. Within symplectic geometry, knot contact homology motivates a close study of a new type of Floer theory (partially wrapped Floer homology); in knot theory, it is conjecturally related to topological concepts like Seifert genus and concordance; in topological string theory, it is conjectured to be determined by a certain Calabi-Yau manifold that has been the object of much study in recent years. Besides tackling these conjectures, the Principal Investigator will pursue a related project, following on a recently discovered connection between constructible sheaves (from algebraic geometry) on one side, and holomorphic curves on the other. This project will develop this connection, in particular working to define an analogue of the Fukaya category for contact manifolds and applying this to facilitate computations in Fukaya categories and mirror symmetry.

por.por_cntn:
Symplectic geometry is a subject that dates back to the study of classical mechanics in physics, and its combination of flexible and rigid phenomena has attracted a great deal of interest in the past few decades. On the rigid side, the technique of counting holomorphic curves in symplectic manifolds, as pioneered by Gromov, Floer, and others, has played a crucial role in the development of low-dimensional topology. This project explored holomorphic curves in symplectic topology as a way to construct computable invariants in low-dimensional topology, specifically invariants of knots and contact manifolds.

Intellectual merit:

The research supported by this grant focused on applications of holomorphic-curve techniques in two related directions in low-dimensional topology and symplectic topology. In the direction of low-dimensional topology, the PI, in collaboration with Tobias Ekholm, discovered a new framework for using symplectic topology to analyze recurrence relations of knot polynomials in knot theory. Specifically, Ekholm and the PI laid out a construction for a version of Symplectic Field Theory for conormal tori of knots and links, building on the PI?s previous work on the knot invariant known as knot contact homology, and proposed a method for using Symplectic Field Theory to produce the recurrence relation for colored HOMFLY-PT knot polynomials as studied in quantum topology. This developed an unexpected connection between the separate fields of symplectic topology and knot theory. It also strengthened an existing link between symplectic topology and the field of topological string theory in physics; this link involves quantum curves and is an ongoing subject of study that has been fruitful for both subjects.

In a different direction, the PI studied Legendrian knots, a key class of knots in three-dimensional space, through augmentations, an algebraic construction from holomorphic curves that has emerged in the past half decade as a key tool for analyzing Legendrian knots. In joint work with Baptiste Chantraine and Steven Sivek, the PI constructed a category, the representation category, built out of certain augmentations of Legendrian knots, and verified special cases of a conjecture that it is equivalent to a category of constructible sheaves from algebraic geometry. Roger Casals and the PI built a framework for applying augmentations over certain coefficient rings as a tool to distinguish between Lagrangian fillings of Legendrian knots, and used this framework to construct families of Legendrian knots that have infinitely many distinct Lagrangian fillings. The PI?s work on augmentations has contributed to a growing direction of research linking symplectic topology to algebraic geometry through the augmentation-sheaf correspondence.

Broader impacts:

During the course of this grant, the PI undertook a number of activities to support and promote research in mathematics at the undergraduate level. Most significantly, the PI served as the director for DOmath, a summer program in collaborative mathematical research organized by the Duke University Mathematics Department. Over the period of this grant, DOmath involved 72 undergraduate students working on 23 research projects; a number of these students were directly funded by this grant. The PI also supervised the research of 3 postdoctoral fellows, 3 graduate students (with 2 earning their Ph.D. degrees and 1 nearing completion), and 1 undergraduate student. In addition, the PI wrote a survey paper with John Etnyre on Legendrian contact homology, which filled a hole in the expository literature and has served as an accessible introduction for researchers and graduate students working in the subject.
